Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the extent of poverty under President Obama by stating that "more Americans are in poverty...than at any time since the Census Bureau began keeping records on it over 50 years ago."
Understate: The claim understates the fact that the poverty rate in 2010 (15.1 percent) is lower than the highest poverty rate recorded in 1959 (22.4 percent).
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that more Americans are in poverty under President Obama than at any time in history.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the increase in poverty, such as population growth or economic factors beyond the control of the president.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the poverty rate in 2010 was not the highest in history, as it was lower than the rate in 1959 and several other years.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in poverty is solely attributable to President Obama's policies, without considering other factors or external influences.
